refstack/api/utils.py.message:
You should be able to avoid subprocessing out here, this is just calling python code and keep it all in memory too. Doing something like::

  import io
  from subunit import filters
  from subunit import StreamResultToBytes
  import testtools

  v2_file = io.BytesIO()
  filters.run_tests_from_stream(
      subunit_file,
      testtools.ExtendedToStreamDecorator(
          StreamResultToBytes(v2_file)))
  v2_file.seek(0)
  return v2_file

Again, this is also python code. You should be able to avoid shelling out to python again. This code is almost identical to: https://github.com/openstack-infra/puppet-subunit2sql/blob/master/files/subunit-gearman-worker.py#L81-L115

Doing it all in python natively should also avoid you needing to play the games with session management you are here. Where you need to make sure you commit in both processes to ensure they get the same state when there are subsequent reads from the db. You can just use the same session for everything and then you don't have to worry.

Also if you want to avoid doing a second call here you could probably just implement a copy of (or propose a subunit2sql patch to make it return) subunit2sql.shell.process_results() here that will return the run uuid instead of the doing an additional query.

I'm not sure the exact call path for this (I might not have gotten far enough in the patch, or just missed where subunit_to_test_results() is called) but this function is basically already implemented in the parse path for subunit2sql: https://github.com/openstack-infra/subunit2sql/blob/master/subunit2sql/read_subunit.py#L144-L152

Oops, didn't finish my though here. But depending on where this is used you can just leverage the use wall time flag with subunit2sql and then you'll store this run_time in the database. So you can just get that directly with a simple query instead of having to calculate it out of band like this.

As written now a path like /build/html/my-html-build-instructions.html will end up looking for /source/html/my-rst-source-instructions.rst which is not likely to exist (or might be something else entirely).

It would be safer to use os.path.splitext(), replace '/build/html/' with '/source/' and then append the new extension. Or better yet, to tell the script to scan 'doc/build/html' and then remove that prefix from the filenames so the 'doc/source' prefix can just be added.

ended up overhauling the entirety of how the last modified time of a given file is found, so this didn't end up getting addressed, but it ended up being replaced by more functional methodology regardless, so this shouldn't end up being an issue
Will this time reflect when the file was checked out from the git repo or the last time a commit modified the source file?

because the build file is not tracked by git, ended up finding the corresponding source file, and then using git log to find the date of the last commit that touched that file. Unfortunately, gitpython is awful at performing actions in another git repo, I ended up shelling out because I wasn't aware of a better solution to this problem, but if there's a known solution that is more optimal, I'd be glad to use it.

Having this hard-coded here for now is OK, but long term we don't want to have yet another place where we store the "status" of a given release series. We already maintain this information in the openstack-manuals repo and to some degree in the releases repo, so it would be good for us to figure out a way to centralize all of that in one location and reuse the data. We can address that later once we have the first version of the tool working.
I tried to think of a way to do this without needing live access, but nothing came to mind

We should not need to do any live web access for this job. The sitemap being built will only contain files that are about to be copied to the web server as a later step in the job. They all exist and will all return 200 when accessed after the sync. They may not exist on the web server at the time the job runs, though, because pages can be added to the docs.
Done

The release series can be determined by examining the branch on which the job is running. That's something we'll need to pass through from zuul to this script, so the script doesn't need to figure it out for itself.
Done
The use of weekly and daily for update frequency feels backwards in this section. Content being actively maintained feels more likely to be updated more often, doesn't it?
Done
I think we just want the mode to be 'w' and we probably need to be setting the encoding for the output to be safe.
Done
This appears to be turning the data into a JSON string then parsing it again. Why is that necessary?
Done
I think we probably only want to scan doc/build/html and not doc/source.
Done
Since the main user of the data zips it together to iterate over it in one loop, perhaps this function should return a single list of tuples instead of 2 separate lists.
Done

This now assumes that files are named uniquely even if they appear in different directories. That won't be the case for any of the index.rst files that turn into index.html.

If the purpose of this function is to convert the path to a built file back to its source name, it should be possible to do that without scanning the filesystem just by applying transformations to the input path name.

See below for a suggestion on how to do that based on the initial file scan.

Under python 3 we will need to decode the output to convert from encoded bytes to a unicode string. It's safe to do that under python 2 as well, so you could add ".decode('utf-8')" to the end of line 31 to be future-proof.
Done

It seems like the priority and changefreq values aren't really tied to the file (they apply to all files based on release and release_eol, right?). Would it make sense to move those to a separate function that is called once from create_sitemap() to get those values?

I'm actually not quite sure that the way I'm going about this is quite comprehensive enought. The commit that triggers this process does not necessarily touch all of the files in the sitemap, so to update all of their sitemap entries is, I think, perhaps incorrect. I may have it touch only the entries pertaining to files that have been updated, rather than having it write over all of them and generate them anew.

Because of the way we publish content, it will be simpler to regenerate the entire sitemap rather than trying to update the file in place. It seems like more work for the program to do, but it makes it easier to reason about what the program is doing and it's just robot time not human time so it doesn't matter if it takes a few seconds longer.

Keep in mind that we're not rebuilding the entire sitemap for docs.o.o every time. We are only building a sub-sitemap for the content being published out of the current repo, which will end up in a docs.o.o/$project/$series directory when it is published. nova/conductor/manager.py.message:
This should probably be wrapped in a try/except for InstanceNotFound in case the instance was deleted during the operation:

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/688832/2/nova/conductor/manager.py
Done
This is a non-free operation, right? You said it's is not an issue for same-cell resize, but we're incurring the cost in that case anyway?

It's not free no. However, it's not entirely cross-cell only if the same-cell migration task blows up *before* casting to the dest host and the instance status is changed somehow. So from the time the task executes to we get here:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/f28839b523186121b6481e607321ddbff370cfc5/nova/conductor/tasks/migrate.py#L368

Let's say we add code at some point that changes the vm_state on the instance and this would blow it away. That's not an issue now, but this would future proof against that.

If we really wanted to restrict the refresh to only cross-cell resize we could check to see if the task created the Migration record yet and if so, if Migration.cross_cell_move is True. However, that's probably also a DB query to get the latest copy of the migration record, so it's also not free.

And finally, even in the same-cell case, if the instance were deleted concurrently while the task was executing, this would also trip the InstanceNotFound so we don't blow up trying to send a notification on a deleted instance, which is something I found while writing tests for bug 1848343.

So I don't think it's worthwhile to try and make this tricky, especially since we're already in an Exception block and basically dead in the water for this operation.

It's not free, but not super harmful considering all the other DB traffic we do in the process of a single migration. I definitely don't want to get into the business of checking the same-cell-ness of a migration everywhere to gate stuff like this, especially things related to consistency.

Ack, thanks for the explanation.

I actually missed that we were in a(nother) exception block already :(
Yeah, I figured the alternative (checking same-cell-ness) would be worse. Thanks for confirming my understanding at least.

  - If I wanted to provide testdata that was unrelated to golden Cmd output, how would I do that?
  - Am I encouraged to use subtests?
  - When should I error vs fatal (too basic?)
  - What kind of utilities are available for me in testutil/
  - If I need to mock an API, what should I use?
...
testing library is not used to mock packages. It is just for creating test fixtures.

I guess it would lead to code having mix usage of standard testing library and testify. Probably sticking to stock testing package is good enough.
Testify has 3 sub packages i.e assertions, mock and suite. It's better to clarify whether using suite subpackage is allowed or not because that will change the way how tests are written/structured. The functionality of mock and assertion library is really minimal. My suggestion is to select specialized libraries for each of these purposes. I would say, 'testify' don't do justice to any of these subtasks.
subtests are useful in table-driven tests but usually create a lot of clutter in code otherwise.

Usually package name should be kept same for the unit tests. Because unit tests may want to test internal helper functions which are not exposed outside. For external package tests this requirement is ok.
So, should this be mandatory?

/COMMIT_MSG.message: I have kind of feel, this title will confuse people with this spec https://review.openstack.org/509042

Alex, yeah, you're probably right :) Might be worth putting a sentence or two in the commit message explaining the difference. Something like this would work I think?

Note that there is another related proposal called "count-quota-usage-from-placement" (https://review.openstack.org/509042). That proposal focuses on converting the existing cell-by-cell quota usage calculations for *existing* quota-limited resources (cores, RAM, instances) into one or more calls to the Placement service's /usages API endpoint. This proposal, on the other hand, focuses on expanding the set of quota-limited resources to any resource class supported by the Placement API, not just the ones traditionally referenced by Nova.

specs/rocky/approved/count-quota-based-o.message:
recommend being explicit about what kind of resource you are talking about here. You're talking here about types of resources that are limited by quota as opposed to resources that are consumed in the placement API.

For example, the quota-limited resource is called "cores", but that resource class is called VCPU in the placement API (and elsewhere in Nova as well, as you know).

Maybe something like this would help?

 .. note::

     The terminology around resources can be quite confusing. There
     are things that are limited by quota, and there are things
     that are consumed by an instance. Both are referred to as "resources"
     in most of the documentation. In this spec, when we
     say "resources", we refer to the things that are limited
     by quota.

     Some of these quota-limited resources are directly related
     to the resources that are consumed by an instance in Nova, however
     the quota-limited resource is named differently. An example
     of this would be the "cores" quota-limited resource is a
     direct relation to the "VCPU" resource that is consumed
     by instances.

     Other quota-limited resources have no direct relationship
     to resources that are consumed by instances. An example of 
     one of these would be the "instances" quota-limited resource.
     This quota-limited resource refers to the total number of
     Nova instances that the user/project is able to have active.
     Clearly, there is no resource that is consumed by a single
     Nova instance that represents a count of *all* the instances
     able to be created by a user.
yes, agree with you, we create another confusing word in the nova :) Thanks for the note
s/Nova is more flexible to manage more kind of/Nova manages additional kinds of/
s/for an end user, it is allowed to create 100 instances, but/an end user may have an "instances" quota of 100 instances, but/
s/to limit the end user on the number of VGPU created to 20/to limit the number of VGPUs the end user can create to 20/
s/the/a/
instances, thereby creating 100 VGPUs.
s/created/create
"wants to limit VGPU consumption"
"wants to limit the consumption of a particular custom resource"
"wants to limit the consumption of a particular kind of baremetal node"

I believe we should be storing the quota limits in Keystone's limits API now, yes?

<later> Never mind, I see you mention Keystone in the alternatives section :) and that Keystone's lack of user dimension is what prevents you from using it at the moment.

Looks like I've been out of the loop on unified limits -- they were added in queens and include an optional user_id [1]. So, the user_id thing won't block us from using unified limits _but_ the lack of quota classes in unified limits will.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/keystone/queens/admin/identity-unified-limits.html

Yes -- I had been thinking that there was no equivalent functionality in the keystone unified limits API _but_ I chatted with Lance yesterday and learned that there is indeed an equivalent API called "registered limits" [1]. So we can use that instead of the quota class API (if we're going to implement this using unified limits, that is).

[1] https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/identity/v3/index.html#create-registered-limits

What we should consider at here, like, what the progress of keystone limits, whether deprecate the user quota,  when we can migrate to keystone limits. Then we will know whether we should do this in the nova quota or keystone limit.

Thinking of what I can do now
Do you mean the quota class API?

Just FYI, it's been discussed before at the Boston Forum that we're thinking to drop "user quota" going forward to keystone unified limits and that nova doesn't actually have need of the user dimension [1]. Originally, quotas in nova were project-only and the user dimension was added later and awkwardly.

Since it's been so long, it probably has to be discussed and refreshed again but at the time, operators in the room were supportive of the idea of dropping user quota going toward keystone and thus dropping it from nova when nova moves to keystone limits.

[1] https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/BOS-forum-quotas

++ thanks for making this clear. os-quota-class-sets needs to be used if the operator wants to set default quota that spans across projects, os-quota-sets needs to be used to set a value for a specific project or user.

That's where I'm confused. You should mention that a CountableResource can have a specific method for counting it, so a "Placement resource class" quota class should implement that method for calling GET /usages
Yes, I plan to have sub-class PlacementCountableResource of CountableResource, and overwrite the count_as_dict method.

OK, I understand your point better now.

So, instead of prefixing resource class names with the service name, we could add a namespace field to the resource_classes table.

For the existing resource classes we could default resource_classes.namespace to "compute".

To handle the "2 Novas, 1 Placement" problem, we can use aggregates and allow GET /usages to filter on an aggregate.

For example, let all the resource providers in Nova 1 be associated with aggregate X. Let all the resource providers in Nova 2 be associated with aggregate Y.

We could get the quota usage counts in Nova 2 by doing:

 GET /usages?project_id=$PROJECT&member_of=$AGG_Y

As mentioned on the other spec (counting usage from placement), I wanted to remind everybody that we might still be potentially blocked from using placement /usages as a count because of the lack of ability to specify an "owner" or "type" when we request usages. There was been discussion the past couple of cycles about whether or not we can assume that _nova_ PUT the allocations associated with the usages we want in placement. If another service could PUT VCPU or RAM resources, for example, we could have ambiguity and be unsure the usage is what we actually wanted.

I have been wondering, could we do something like namespace resource classes so that whichever service PUT the resource (example, nova:VCPU and nova:RAM) and then when calling GET /usages the caller can access the namespace of their own (if that is what they wish to count). Would that be a simple solution for being able to differentiate resources for the purposes of querying /usages?
Another remind, for the consumer type, we also have migration uuid as the consumer, that is also the one we want to filter out in the usage count.

Yeah, sorry, let me try to explain what I meant there. I'm not talking about non-quantifiable resources like "instances" here (though true, originally when "owner" or "type" came up in the past, it was in the context of counting "instances").

Totally agree we can slice and dice via project/user, which gets us most of the way there. The last potential wrinkle is the assumption that VCPU and MEMORY_MB came from nova. That nova is the service that PUT /allocations of them. So that when we see them in /usages, we know we are getting VCPU and MEMORY_MB about instances.

In the past discussions about allocations, in placement land it was pointed out that _any service_ can put allocations in placement. So, (hypothetical) what if some service WhizBang PUT /allocations for VCPU and MEMORY_MB. And nova also PUT /allocations for VCPU and MEMORY_MB. Then, when nova goes to GET /usages, the VCPU and MEMORY_MB contain usage for both the nova service and the WhizBang service.

I was thinking, to solve that problem, would it make sense to simply allow namespacing of resources? So that if nova PUT /allocations for VCPU and MEMORY_MB, it could know which ones are nova by instead PUTing /allocations for nova:VCPU and nova:MEMORY_MB and GET /usages will have entries for nova:VCPU nova:MEMORY_MB whizbang:VCPU whizbang:MEMORY_MB.

I was just trying to think if the "owner" or "type" problem could be as simply solved with allowing namespacing of resources.

This is starting to get into the territory that https://review.openstack.org/#/c/509042/3/specs/rocky/approved/count-quota-usage-from-placement.rst covers. Probably worth limiting the scope of this blueprint to expanding the set of *resources* that may be quota-limited to include any resource class that is tracked via the placement API (and the associated resources=$RESOURCE_CLASS:$AMOUNT extra-spec keys in Nova).

Well, any allocation created after or at placement API version 1.8 will include a user and project identifier. So, all allocations for any resource will be sliceable/diceable by both the user and project.

Of course, that doesn't allow us to query for non-quantifiable quota classes like "instances". But that's not due to anything related to the placement API. That's primarily due to the fact that those types of resources are inherently non-quantifiable. They aren't quantifiable because "number of instances" isn't actually able to be expressed as an amount of some underlying resources (VCPU, MEMORY_MB, etc).

For that reason, I'm afraid as long as we continue to require quota counts for non-quantifiable resources like "instances", then we will need to express those counts using non-placement API queries -- which is what you've suggested in your spec in using a query on the instance_mappings table to do just that.

did you plan on allowing an operator to set default limits via the configuration file for any placement-known resource class?

Note that the "set default values via configuration file" has the problem of "what happens when multiple nodes have different values for the defaults?" issue, similar to the problem we currently have with aggregate allocation ratio defaults (though not configuration-file related... for aggregate allocation ratios, the problem lies in the fact that multiple aggregates can define the same allocation ratio metadata key with different values) :)

Yeah ... I don't think the default values via config could work (per resource) given that PlacementCountableResource can represent multiple resource classes (as users create quota limits dynamically via the os-quota-sets API). That means N resource classes map to one PlacementCountableResource. Which means you would need N configuration options, one per resource class, and you would have to know them ahead of time and can't know them ahead of time because they are created on-the-fly via os-quota-class-sets.

The quota class API will work nicely for setting a default per resource that spans across projects as the order of checking goes: quota set via os-quota-sets, quota set via os-quota-class-sets, config option [1].

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/nova/pike/user/quotas.html#checking-quota

So I think we should move to os_limits (i.e. unified limits) using keystone before we do that.

That way we avoid all the API changes, so I think it would actually be less work using os_limits.

Unified limits are already implemented since queens [1][2] and designated as experimental. We haven't really talked seriously about moving to unified limits in nova. But it would involve migrating our config-option based limits/quota classes/etc to keystone and replacing any database query for quota limits with a call to keystone for limits. It would take some time and effort to come up with a smooth upgrade and migration path.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/keystone/queens/admin/identity-unified-limits.html
[2] https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/identity/v3/index.html#unified-limits

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
Nope, this will cause the manila scheduler to find a valid host in case there are *only* backends that support snapshot-support. 

Here's the behavior in the manila scheduler:

- If "snapshot_support" in a share type is set to True, the scheduler will only match backends that allow taking snapshots. 
- If "snapshot_support" in a share type is set to False, the scheduler will only match backends that do not support snapshots. 
- If "snapshot_support" is not set in a share type, the scheduler places the share on any backend irrespective of whether snapshots or supported or not. However, users will be prevented from taking snapshots of such shares. 

What you really want is the third behavior of the scheduler. This way, you'll force the administrators to specify "snapshot_support" in case they want behaviors 1 or 2.

So... based on the note later in this doc, "As of the Stein release, the openstack server create command does not support creating a volume-backed server from a source image like the nova boot command," none of these should be referencing the 'openstack server create' command.

But, as of OSC 4.0.0 there is the --boot-from-volume option, so should this be reworked to use that instead?

[--block-device-mapping <dev-name=mapping>]


--block-device-mapping <dev-name=mapping>

    Create a block device on the server. Block device mapping in the format <dev-name>=<id>:<type>:<size(GB)>:<delete-on-terminate> <dev-name>: block device name, like: vdb, xvdc (required) <id>: Name or ID of the volume, volume snapshot or image (required) <type>: volume, snapshot or image; default: volume (optional) <size(GB)>: volume size if create from image or snapshot (optional) <delete-on-terminate>: true or false; default: false (optional) (optional extension)

deliverables/train/magnum.yaml.message:
Could you please add below highlights?

1. Fedora CoreOS driver

Finally we get this done in this cycle which is quite important and
urgent. Because the Fedora Atomic will be end of life soon (at the end
of this Nov?). Now with stable/train, user can create k8s cluster based
on Fedora CoreOS image. We're welcome for any feedback about this.

2. Node group

This is a quite large feature, thanks for the great work from CERN team
and StackHPC. With this feature, user can create different node groups
with different specs.

3. Rolling upgrade

Now user can do rolling upgrade for both k8s version and the node
operating system without downtime, it's a quite important feature.

4. Auto healing

With auto healing feature, a small service will be deployed on k8s
cluster to monitor the health status of the cluster and replace broken
node when failure detected.

5. Volume based k8s nodes

Now user can create a Kubernetes cluster with nodes based on volume and
the volume type is configurable. User can even set the volume type of
etcd volume which is very useful for cloud providers who want to use SSD
for etcd and k8s nodes.

6. Private cluster

As a security best practice, isolating Kubernetes clusters from Internet
access is one of the most desired features for enterprise users. Now
user has the flexibility to create a private cluster by default, only
allow the API exposed on Internet or fully opened.
It's a little late for highlights to be useful, but I think this would be good to add in a separate patch for historical reference.
Indentation is off here. I highly recommend using new-release rather than editing these by hand.

nova/network/neutronv2/api.py.message:
Looks ok, because of the same condition upper, but 
two questions:

- Why could context.auth_token be false? I thought after successful auth it had to contain token, right?

- You are turning off context.is_admin if not auth_token, does it affect exceptions only or some logic also?
Done

Can we put a comment in this code explaining the logic turducken we now have here?

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Turducken

This is done specifically, so that we raise the correct exception in ClientWrapper, when the token expires - i.e. Unauthorized at #107 and *not* NeutronAdminCredentialConfigurationInvalid at #115.

Condition `(context.is_admin and not context.auth_token)` denotes a request to Neutron issued from *within* Nova using the 
*service credentials*  from nova.conf. 

`context.is_admin and context.auth_token`, on the other hand, would be a a request to nova-api performed by a user with admin role (e.g. ceilometer polling agent), that also needs to go to neutron-sever on behalf of that user, i.e. using the given `auth_token`.

The problem here was that we raised an incorrect exception in the case when a token nova-api was given expired right at the moment when it reached neutron-server: instead of propagating 401 back to the user, who did the request (in my case - ceilometer-polling-agent), we mistakenly treated that as a configuration error, as if the neutron credentials in nova.conf were incorrect (although we did not use them at all for this kind of request to neutron-server).
This belongs in the docstring for __init__, not the class.
Done
Hmm, maybe is_token_from_config would be a better name for this?
Done
By the way, if you enable the service token stuff, you can't ever hit the user token expiry problem you talk about.

Yeah, good point. IIRC, I saw this problem on Mitaka, so this seemed to be an easier solution, but overall service token sounds like the best way to solve this in the long term perspective (maybe Ceilo already does that, I haven't checked master).

So this is good.

But maybe we should rename the admin param to something like suppress_401_errors or is_token_from_config?
Done
Done

sdague suggested calling it "auth_from_config" in the original change that introduced this code:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/312014/14/nova/network/neutronv2/api.py
grammatically-incorrect comma usage. Just remove it.
semicolon and a single space would be better here.
this wording around False isn't the whole story... just say "False otherwise", which is both sufficient and more correct.
remove blank line
s/In the long term perspective/Long term/
Maybe we cannot remove the later one, as right now we are leveraging the later one to handle case when "token has expired".

if auth was done with user/password, then the session should automatically get a new token when the current one expires. Only if auth was done with a token should we need to call get_client again when the token expires, and we can only really do that if we want an admin token because we don't have user/pwd for anything else, so we should explicitly pass admin=True there. So I think it's right that long-term we would probably remove (2).

The problem is sometimes we do not explicitly pass admin=True when call get_client(In my environment _get_available_networks). When token expired, as context.auth_token still contains token id, if we remove(2), these API calls will fail with exception NeutronAdminCredentialConfigurationInvalid.
it wouldn't be removed without updating places like that to explicitly pass admin=True.
